transcripts.text: And I guess I don't know much about Billings, Montana.  I mean, the relationship there.  How many African-Americans live there?  Have you have there been any issues with the police there or not?

Yes, there's been a lot.  Actually, I've been having a lot of calls and messages about getting a group together because they are.  They are very horrible here.  And I hate to have to put this on air, but my best friend told me to say it, and I'm just going to go ahead and say it.  Even after that, the next day, when the thing went viral, I went to go pay my rent on the first, and the police followed me for 20 minutes.

For 20 minutes.  And yes, I was swerving through traffic and I had to make sure somebody stayed behind me so I couldn't get pulled over.  The man wanted to pull me over.  They're not playing with me.  They're not playing.  I don't know if I should say that on air, but it is what it is.

Well, no, you matter of fact, people need to know that because the reality is that is brand new.  So so you you are now at least in this one situation, you being followed.  Do you feel like they're still tracking you and following you?

Yes, it's dead serious.  That's not a joke.  They were following me and my husband for 20 minutes.  My husband was very nervous.  I was crying.  I had a panic attack.  I had to let him drive, literally, literally.  When we got to the height close to my house, he had to turn around because it wasn't his district.
